#Text=Abgar Ali
#Text=Akbar Armani
#Text=Abgar was an Armenian of the Safavid Empire who lived during the reign of Shah ( King ) Suleiman I ( r.1666-1694 ) .
#Text=Originally a merchant , he later converted from Christianity to Shia Islam and took the name Abgar Ali Akbar Armani .
#Text=Over time , he became estranged from the Armenian community , and increasingly associated with members of the Safavid clergy and later married into their families .
#Text=He wrote a conversion narrative in Persian , the Eterāfnāme ( " Confession Book " ) , which was conceived perhaps as a missionary tool , and for circulation among Armenian Christians .

column1: #Text=According to Alberto Tibrucio , this work " fills an important gap as a rare example of a testimony narrated from the perspective of a convert and portraying a voluntary conversion " . [ 1 ]
#Text=Biography
#Text=What little is known about his life is largely drawn from his work , the Eterāfnāme ( " Confession Book " ) .

column1: #Text=Born Abgar , possibly in New Julfa , the Armenian quarter of Isfahan , he spent the early part of his life as a merchant .

#Text=He may have been a member of either the renowned Velijanian ( or Veligianian ) merchant family of Venice or the Sceriman ( Shahremanian ) family , although the latter is considered less likely .

#Text=Around 1673 , during the reign of Safavid Shah ( King ) Suleiman I , he converted from Christianity to Shia Islam , a decision which , according to his writings , was inspired by a scriptural evidence as well as a series of visions and dreams .
#Text=At the time of his conversion , he had been in contact with the Armenian mayor ( kalāntar ) of New Julfa , Hajji Piri , who was also a convert . [ 2 ]
#Text=Armani reportedly became estranged from his family after being branded an apostate .

#Text=His subsequent trip to Venice resulted in his imprisonment " in retaliation for allegations of mistreatment of Christians in Iran " , but he was later released through the intervention of his brother .

column1: #Text=After his release , he journeyed to the Ottoman cities of Constantinople and Belgrade before returning to Isfahan via the Safavid cities of Erivan , Tabriz and Mashhad . [ 2 ]
#Text=He is known to have married on numerous occasions and sired a number of children with his various wives . [ 2 ]
#Text=After his conversion , he increasingly associated with members of the Safavid ulama , and would marry into their families . [ 3 ]
#Text=His first wife , whom he met her during his journey , was the daughter of a judge and hailed from Constantinople . [ 2 ]
#Text=According to Alberto Tiburcio , he was persecuted in Constantinople " for his assumed Shi'i allegiance as an Iranian " . [ 2 ]
#Text=However , it appears that at the time Armani was not yet an adherent of Shia Islam , at least not initially , but had developed a Shi'ite identity through the course of his journey . [ 2 ]
#Text=In later life , his relations with the Armenian community would deteriorate to the point that he became a target of their persecution .
#Text=Tiburcio wrote that , in retaliation , Armani " claims to have engaged in a quasi-ritual cursing of Armenian priests , leading to the death of the latter " . [ 3 ] .
#Text=Armani died sometime after 27 January 1708 , possibly in Isfahan . [ 2 ]
#Text=Work
#Text=Armani 's work , the Eterāfnāme , was completed on 27 January 1708 and was written entirely in Persian . [ 4 ]
#Text=Only one manuscript of this conversion narrative , consisting of 73 folios , is extant and is stored in the University of Tehran . [ 4 ]

#Text=According to Tiburcio , the Eterāfnāme , though written in Persian , was probably conceived as a missionary tool and for circulation among Armenian Christians " as far as the surviving evidence suggests " . [ 4 ]
#Text=Its prose is simple , yet " rich in symbolism " , and describes Armani 's conversion and travels . [ 4 ]

#Text=His use of " oneiric elements " in his work to describe his " spiritual journey into Islam " has led Tiburcio to suggest that he had access to conversion narratives stemming from other milieus . [ 4 ]

column1: #Text=The work also includes the " standard " biblical reference to the Paraclete of the Gospel of John , an example of inter-religious polemic often used in conversion narratives to express " proof " for Islam from the Bible . [ 4 ]

#Text=Though the Persian chronicles , European travelogues and correspondences between Christian missionaries reveal that many converted from Christianity to Islam during the Safavid period , they only depict instances where the converts were either forced to convert or did so out of convenience . [ 1 ]
#Text=Such accounts generally do not provide insights into the personal views of the converts . [ 1 ]
#Text=According to Tiburcio , the Eterāfnāme " fills an important gap as a rare example of a testimony narrated from the perspective of a convert and portraying a voluntary conversion " . [ 1 ]
